faqs.question: What is the exam pattern for B.Tech programs?
faqs.answer: The B.Tech programs follow a semester system with continuous assessment, including mid-term exams, assignments, and end-semester exams.

faqs.question: What facilities are available on campus?
faqs.answer: The campus offers a library, hostels, sports complexes, and various labs equipped with modern technology.

academics.question: What is the purpose of the Fully Flexible Credit System (FFCS)?
academics.answer: The Fully Flexible Credit System (FFCS) allows students to register courses of their choice and alter the pace of learning within the broad framework of academic course and credit requirements. It enables students to decide their academic plan and modify it as they progress. FFCS also allows students to choose their own timetable by combining it with a slot-based timetable, making learning more experiential through projects and interdisciplinary courses.

academics.question: What is the minimum attendance requirement for students?
academics.answer: Students are expected to maintain 100% attendance in all courses. However, they are permitted to maintain an attendance of 75% (i.e., absent for 25% of instructional hours) in each course without providing proof for the absence. This 25% absence includes medical, personal, casual, official leave, and participation in co-curricular or extra-curricular events.

academics.question: What are the consequences of not meeting the minimum attendance requirement?
academics.answer: Students who fail to meet the minimum attendance requirement of 75% will be debarred from writing the next evaluation component (CAT/FAT) of the course. They will be awarded an 'N' grade and must re-register the course to clear it.

academics.question: What is the grading system used in FFCS?
academics.answer: The grading system uses letter grades (S, A, B, C, D, E, F, N, W, U, P) with corresponding grade points. A student is declared to have passed a course if they secure a minimum of 40% in the theory FAT, 50% in the laboratory/project components, and 50% in the grand total marks for the course. Grades are awarded based on absolute or relative grading, depending on the course type and class strength.

academics.question: What is the difference between absolute and relative grading?
academics.answer: Absolute grading is based on fixed mark ranges (e.g., S for >= 90, A for >= 80 but < 90, etc.), while relative grading is based on the student's performance relative to their peers in the same class. Relative grading is used for theory courses with a class strength of more than 10, while absolute grading is used for laboratory, soft skills, and project courses.

academics.question: What is the minimum credit requirement for completing a programme?
academics.answer: The minimum credit requirement for completing a programme is specified in the programme curriculum. Students must complete all courses under Foundation Core (FC), Discipline Core (DC), and meet the credit requirements under Open Elective (OE), Discipline Elective (DE), Skill Enhancement Courses (SEC), and Ability Enhancement Courses (AEC) to be eligible for the degree.

academics.question: What is the process for course registration?
academics.answer: Students must register for courses they intend to study in a semester through a Course Registration process. The registration is carried out on specific days declared by the University. Students with outstanding dues can register but cannot attend classes until fees are paid. Late registration is permitted for up to 10 calendar days with the approval of the School Dean and payment of a late fee.

academics.question: What is the role of a Proctor in FFCS?
academics.answer: A Proctor assists students in planning their academic journey. They discuss the student's academic performance and suggest the number and nature of courses to be registered in the upcoming semester, within the framework of the programme curriculum. The Proctor also helps students with backlogs or those under probation to pace their studies accordingly.

academics.question: What are bridge courses?
academics.answer: Bridge courses are special courses recommended for students based on their proficiency in language or fundamental disciplines. These courses are registered automatically for students who need to compensate for inadequacies identified through screening tests or previous qualifying examinations. The credits and grades from bridge courses do not count toward CGPA or minimum credit requirements.

academics.question: What is the maximum and minimum number of credits a student can register in a semester?
academics.answer: In a regular semester, students can register for a maximum of 27 credits and a minimum of 16 credits. However, students with a CGPA below 4.0 are advised to register for a maximum of 16 credits. There is no minimum or maximum credit limit for summer or weekend semesters.

academics.question: What is the process for re-registering backlog courses?
academics.answer: Students who have not cleared one or more components of a course (Theory/Lab) are awarded an 'N' grade. If a student clears all components but fails to meet the passing range, an 'F' grade is awarded. Both 'F' and 'N' grades require re-registration of the course in subsequent semesters. Students must pay a re-registration fee for re-registering backlog courses.

academics.question: What is the procedure for adding or dropping courses?
academics.answer: Students can add or drop courses during the first three instructional days of the semester, subject to resource availability and credit limits. Courses dropped during this period will not appear in the semester grade sheet. Add/Drop is not available for summer or weekend semesters.

academics.question: What is the process for course withdrawal?
academics.answer: If a student is unsatisfied with their performance in CAT-I, they can withdraw from the course after CAT-I marks are finalized. Course withdrawal is permitted for three instructional days, and withdrawn courses are marked with a 'W' grade. Withdrawal below 16 credits is generally not permitted, except for final-year or timed-out students.

academics.question: What are the prerequisites for registering a course?
academics.answer: Some courses have prerequisites that must be met before registration. Students who have received an 'F' grade in a prerequisite course are still permitted to register for the next level course, assuming they have gained the required exposure. Anti-requisites and co-requisites may also apply to certain courses.

academics.question: What is the assessment and evaluation process for courses?
academics.answer: Courses are assessed through Continuous Assessment Tests (CAT-I and CAT-II), Digital Assignments, and a Final Assessment Test (FAT). CAT-I and CAT-II are worth 15 marks each, and the FAT is worth 40 marks. The total continuous assessment marks account for 60% of the grade, while the FAT accounts for 40%. Laboratory and project courses have separate evaluation criteria.

academics.question: What is the process for re-evaluation of answer sheets?
academics.answer: Students can apply for re-evaluation of their FAT answer sheets within a specified time period by paying a fee. If the re-evaluation results in a change of more than 5% in marks, the answer sheet is evaluated again by a different examiner. The best of the three evaluations is considered for grading.

academics.question: What is the procedure for absence from an exam?
academics.answer: Students who miss CAT-I due to valid reasons (e.g., internships, health issues) can apply for a Re-CAT-I with prior permission from the School Dean. Students who miss the FAT due to hospitalization or family emergencies can apply for a Re-FAT within 14 calendar days, supported by proper documentation.

academics.question: What is the process for grade improvement?
academics.answer: Students can register for a course again in a subsequent semester to improve their grade. This is allowed only once per course, and students must pay an additional fee. Grade improvement courses are treated as additional courses and do not affect the maximum credit limit.

academics.question: What is the Semester Abroad Program (SAP)?
academics.answer: The Semester Abroad Program allows undergraduate and postgraduate students to study at partner universities abroad and earn credits. Students can transfer a maximum of 21 credits, excluding UG/PG project work. The program is available during specific semesters, and students must have a CGPA of 7.0 or higher with no current backlogs.

academics.question: What is the Honours Club?
academics.answer: The Honours Club is for students who maintain a CGPA of 9.25 or higher, have no 'F' grades, and have never been debarred for attendance or indiscipline. Members receive benefits such as preference for seminars/conferences, certificates of merit, and cash awards or scholarships.

academics.question: What is the time limit for completing a programme?
academics.answer: The minimum period of study for a programme is specified in Annexure 1. Students are allowed an additional grace period of three years ('n+3') to complete backlog courses. If a student fails to complete the programme within this period, their studentship is automatically cancelled.

academics.question: What is the process for awarding a degree?
academics.answer: After completing the course and credit requirements, students receive a Provisional Certificate. The degree is conferred during the subsequent convocation. The degree certificate indicates the branch, specialization, and any minor or honours earned by the student.

academics.question: What is the process for modifying regulations?
academics.answer: The Academic Council has the right to add, delete, or modify the FFCS regulations. Any disputes in interpreting the rules are resolved by the Academic Council, and their decision is final and binding.

academics.question: What are the timelines for student project evaluations?
academics.answer: The timelines for student project evaluations are as follows: 1st Review (5% weightage) during the first week of the semester, 2nd Review (40% weightage) during the CAT-I period, submission of draft project report (5% weightage) 10 calendar days before the viva voce exam, synopsis submission 7 calendar days before the viva voce exam, and final project report submission one instructional day before the viva voce exam. The final viva voce exam (50% weightage) is conducted during the FAT period.

academics.question: What are the rules for audit courses?
academics.answer: Audit courses allow students to gain exposure to a course without earning a grade. Students can register a maximum of two audit courses during their entire programme, provided their CGPA is 8.0 or higher. Audit courses require maintaining minimum attendance, and students must undergo all assessments. If a student fails to complete an audit course, they receive a 'W' grade. Audit courses do not count toward GPA or CGPA.

academics.question: What are the rules for industrial internships?
academics.answer: All students must undergo a four-week industrial internship in a reputed industry, which can be completed in one stretch or two two-week stretches. Students maintain a digital log of their activities and submit a report and completion certificate. Marks are awarded based on the log, report, and viva voce performance. The internship is evaluated by an Industrial Internship Evaluation Committee.

academics.question: What are the rules for UG Research Experience (URE)?
academics.answer: UG Research Experience (URE) includes project-type courses like TARP, Design Project, Laboratory Project, and Simulation Project. Each course carries 3 credits and is evaluated based on the student's performance in the project. Students can register for one course at a time and must complete it before registering for another. The credits earned count toward DE or OE requirements.

academics.question: What are the rules for course equivalence?
academics.answer: Course equivalence allows students to register for a course with a modified syllabus if the changes are marginal. The Course Committee determines equivalence, and students must complete the new syllabus. The original course code and title are reflected in the grade sheet, and credits are awarded based on the original course.

men's hostel.question: What is the rule regarding attendance in the hostel?
men's hostel.answer: Students must be available in their respective rooms as attendance will be taken in their respective blocks at 9.00 pm every night.

men's hostel.question: Can students stay in rooms other than the one allotted to them?
men's hostel.answer: No, students should stay only in the room allotted to them. Staying in another student's room is not permitted.

men's hostel.question: What is the policy on harassment in the hostel?
men's hostel.answer: Any form of physical or mental harassment, including ragging, quarrelling, using abusive language, or violent behaviour, is strictly prohibited.

men's hostel.question: Is smoking allowed in the hostel or on the university campus?
men's hostel.answer: No, smoking is strictly prohibited inside the hostel premises and on the university campus.

men's hostel.question: What are the rules regarding noise and disturbances in the hostel?
men's hostel.answer: Silence should be maintained in the hostel, especially from 9.00 pm to 6.00 am. Students should not disturb others by conducting parties, playing music, or talking loudly on mobile phones.

men's hostel.question: Are Multi-Level Marketing (MLM) and gambling allowed in the hostel?
men's hostel.answer: No, Multi-Level Marketing (MLM) and gambling in any form, including playing cards, are prohibited in the hostel.

men's hostel.question: What are the consequences of possessing or consuming liquor in the hostel?
men's hostel.answer: If a liquor bottle (even empty) is found in any room, all students staying in that room are liable to be suspended for one year. Consuming liquor inside the hostel, bringing liquor into the hostel or campus, or entering the campus/hostel in a drunken state will result in suspension for one year or one semester, respectively.

men's hostel.question: What are the rules regarding narcotics or related substances in the hostel?
men's hostel.answer: If narcotics or related substances are found in any room, all students staying in that room will be expelled from VIT. Consuming, trading, or possessing narcotics inside or outside the hostel will also result in expulsion.

men's hostel.question: What happens if a student damages hostel property?
men's hostel.answer: Anyone causing damage to hostel property will be penalized suitably.

men's hostel.question: Can students bring day-scholars, ex-VITians, or non-VITians into the hostel?
men's hostel.answer: No, hostel students are not allowed to bring day-scholars, ex-VITians, or non-VITians into the hostel premises.

men's hostel.question: How should students apply for leave or permission?
men's hostel.answer: Students must apply for leave or permission through their Student-Login on the VIT website. They should not go to a place other than the one specified in the leave request.

men's hostel.question: Are motor vehicles allowed in the hostel campus?
men's hostel.answer: No, hostellers are not allowed to keep or operate any kind of motor vehicles inside the hostel campus. However, bicycles are permitted.

men's hostel.question: What electrical or electronic equipment are students allowed to keep in their rooms?
men's hostel.answer: Students are not allowed to keep air coolers, TVs, electric iron boxes, or any other unauthorized electrical or electronic equipment/gadgets in their rooms. Unauthorized possession will lead to confiscation of the goods. Cooking in the rooms is also strictly prohibited.

men's hostel.question: What should students do to safeguard their belongings?
men's hostel.answer: Students are personally responsible for safeguarding their belongings. They are advised not to keep large amounts of cash or valuables like gold, expensive watches, laptops, mobile phones, or jewellery in their rooms.

men's hostel.question: What is the process for vacating the hostel and staying outside?
men's hostel.answer: Students who wish to vacate the hostel and stay outside must produce a written consent letter from their parents.

men's hostel.question: Can students stay in the hostel during vacation periods?
men's hostel.answer: Students will not be permitted to stay in the hostels during vacation periods unless they have academic assignments.

men's hostel.question: What is the rule for students staying in the hostel during the summer semester?
men's hostel.answer: Students planning to stay back during the summer semester at hostels must pay the summer semester fees.

men's hostel.question: What are the timings for students to arrive at the campus gate and be in the hostel?
men's hostel.answer: Students must arrive at the campus gate by 6.00 pm and must be inside the hostels by 9.00 pm.

men's hostel.question: What is the fee structure in men's hostel?
men's hostel.answer: The fee structure is variable depending on room size and other regulations, kindly visit the official VIT Chennai website for accurate Fee Details.

ladies/girls/womens hostel.question: What are the timings for students to arrive at the college gate and hostel gate?
ladies/girls/womens hostel.answer: Students must arrive at the college gate by 6:00 PM and at the hostel gate by 8:00 PM.

ladies/girls/womens hostel.question: When should students record their attendance in the hostel?
ladies/girls/womens hostel.answer: Students must record their attendance every day between 7:30 PM and 8:30 PM using the biometric machines without fail.

ladies/girls/womens hostel.question: Can students stay in rooms other than the one allotted to them?
ladies/girls/womens hostel.answer: No, students should stay only in the room allotted to them. Staying in other rooms is not permitted.

ladies/girls/womens hostel.question: Is the room allotted to a student permanent?
ladies/girls/womens hostel.answer: No, the room allotted to a student is not permanent. If necessary, the hostel administration may change the room for maintenance convenience.

ladies/girls/womens hostel.question: What is the policy on harassment in the hostel?
ladies/girls/womens hostel.answer: Any form of physical or mental harassment, including ragging, quarrelling, using abusive language, or violent behaviour, is strictly prohibited and punishable.

ladies/girls/womens hostel.question: Is smoking allowed in the hostel or on the university campus?
ladies/girls/womens hostel.answer: No, smoking is strictly prohibited and punishable inside the hostel premises and on the university campus.

ladies/girls/womens hostel.question: What are the rules regarding noise and disturbances in the hostel?
ladies/girls/womens hostel.answer: Silence should be maintained in the hostel, especially from 9:00 PM to 6:00 AM. Students should not disturb others by conducting parties, playing music, or talking loudly on mobile phones.

ladies/girls/womens hostel.question: Are Multi-Level Marketing (MLM) and gambling allowed in the hostel?
ladies/girls/womens hostel.answer: No, Multi-Level Marketing (MLM) and gambling in any form, including playing cards, are prohibited in the hostel.

ladies/girls/womens hostel.question: Is playing online games allowed in the hostel?
ladies/girls/womens hostel.answer: No, playing online games that disturb the peaceful environment of the hostel is strictly prohibited.

ladies/girls/womens hostel.question: What are the consequences of consuming or possessing alcohol in the hostel?
ladies/girls/womens hostel.answer: Students found entering the university or hostel premises under the influence of alcohol or inducing others to consume alcohol will be suspended for one semester. If a student is found consuming or possessing liquor (even empty bottles) inside the university or hostel premises, they will be suspended for one year.

ladies/girls/womens hostel.question: What are the rules regarding narcotics or related substances in the hostel?
ladies/girls/womens hostel.answer: If narcotics or related substances are found in any room, all students staying in that room will be expelled from the university. Consuming, trading, or possessing narcotics inside or outside the hostel will also result in expulsion. Abuse of any chemicals is strictly prohibited.

ladies/girls/womens hostel.question: What happens if a student damages hostel property?
ladies/girls/womens hostel.answer: Anyone causing damage to hostel property will be penalized suitably.

ladies/girls/womens hostel.question: Can students bring day-scholars, ex-VITians, or non-VITians into the hostel?
ladies/girls/womens hostel.answer: No, hostel students are not allowed to bring day-scholars, ex-VITians, or non-VITians into the hostel premises.

ladies/girls/womens hostel.question: What is the procedure for students going out for an overnight stay?
ladies/girls/womens hostel.answer: If a student is going out for an overnight stay, she must obtain prior permission before leaving the hostel as per the procedure. Violation of this rule is punishable as per norms.

ladies/girls/womens hostel.question: Are motor vehicles allowed in the hostel campus?
ladies/girls/womens hostel.answer: No, hostellers are not allowed to keep or use any kind of motor vehicles inside or outside the campus. However, bicycles are permitted.

ladies/girls/womens hostel.question: What electrical or electronic equipment are students allowed to keep in their rooms?
ladies/girls/womens hostel.answer: Students are not allowed to keep air coolers, musical instruments, cassette record players, electric fans, TVs, electric iron boxes, power extension boxes, kettles, or any other unauthorized electrical equipment/gadgets in their rooms. Unauthorized possession will lead to confiscation of the goods. Cooking in the rooms is strictly prohibited for fire safety reasons.

ladies/girls/womens hostel.question: What should students do to safeguard their belongings?
ladies/girls/womens hostel.answer: Students are personally responsible for safeguarding their belongings. They are advised not to keep large amounts of cash or valuables like gold, expensive watches, or jewellery in their rooms. Students must lock their cupboards and rooms when they leave.

ladies/girls/womens hostel.question: Are students allowed to stay in external hostels or rented houses?
ladies/girls/womens hostel.answer: No, students who live more than 60 km away from the campus must stay in the VIT hostel only. Staying in external hostels or rented houses with friends is not allowed under any circumstances.

ladies/girls/womens hostel.question: What is the procedure for leaving the hostel?
ladies/girls/womens hostel.answer: Leaving the hostel is permitted only after receiving approval via message or email from the parents or local guardian (who must be enrolled in the hostel office with parental approval). On return, a signature from the parents or local guardian is required.

ladies/girls/womens hostel.question: How many times can students go on leave to their hometown or local guardian's place in a month?
ladies/girls/womens hostel.answer: Students are permitted to go on leave to their hometown or local guardian's place only twice a month after approval from their parents or proctor.

ladies/girls/womens hostel.question: Can students stay in the hostel during vacation periods?
ladies/girls/womens hostel.answer: Students will not be permitted to stay in the hostels during vacation periods unless they have academic assignments.

ladies/girls/womens hostel.question: What is the rule for students staying in the hostel during the summer semester?
ladies/girls/womens hostel.answer: Students planning to stay back during the summer semester at hostels must pay the summer semester fees.

ladies/girls/womens hostel.question: What is the dress code for girl students when leaving the hostel premises?
ladies/girls/womens hostel.answer: Girl students are permitted to go out from the hostel premises only in decent dress as per norms.

ladies/girls/womens hostel.question: What is the role of parents or guardians in hostel matters?
ladies/girls/womens hostel.answer: Parents or guardians must report in person when called by the hostel officials. No other friends or relatives will be entertained. Parents or guardians are expected to raise their issues or concerns to the respective in-charge or proctor by referring to the university's official website.

ladies/girls/womens hostel.question: What is the Personal Security Bond and Local Guardian Details?
ladies/girls/womens hostel.answer: The Personal Security Bond is a document signed by the parent/guardian and student, authorizing the university to allow the student to go out of the campus with proper prior intimation. The parent/guardian takes full responsibility for the student's actions. A local guardian must also be designated, and the student may avail leave to visit the local guardian's place as per approved leave regulations.

ladies/girls/womens hostel.question: What happens if a student causes damage to university property?
ladies/girls/womens hostel.answer: The student and parent/guardian are required to indemnify the university for any loss or damage caused by the student. If the damage is not made good within 15 days, the university may recover the loss along with 36% interest per annum.

health facilities.question: Where is the Health Centre located?
health facilities.answer: The Health Centre is located near Academic Block 2.

health facilities.question: Who runs the Health Centre?
health facilities.answer: The Health Centre is currently run by the Apollo Shine Foundation.

health facilities.question: What are the operating hours of the Health Centre?
health facilities.answer: The Health Centre operates 24×7 to cater to students' medical needs.

health facilities.question: What is the helpline number for the Health Centre?
health facilities.answer: The helpline number for the Health Centre is 044 3993 1100.

health facilities.question: What facilities are available at the Health Centre?
health facilities.answer: The Health Centre provides the following facilities: Observation Beds, Consultation Room, Doctor and Staff Nurses, Housekeeping, and 2 Ambulances.

health facilities.question: Does the Health Centre have observation beds?
health facilities.answer: Yes, the Health Centre has observation beds for students who require medical monitoring.

health facilities.question: Is there a consultation room at the Health Centre?
health facilities.answer: Yes, the Health Centre has a consultation room where students can meet with doctors.

health facilities.question: Are there doctors and staff nurses available at the Health Centre?
health facilities.answer: Yes, the Health Centre has doctors and staff nurses available to attend to students' medical needs.

health facilities.question: Does the Health Centre provide housekeeping services?
health facilities.answer: Yes, housekeeping services are available at the Health Centre to maintain cleanliness and hygiene.

health facilities.question: How many ambulances are available at the Health Centre?
health facilities.answer: There are 2 ambulances available at the Health Centre for emergency medical transportation.

health facilities.question: Can students access the Health Centre at any time?
health facilities.answer: Yes, the Health Centre is operational 24×7, so students can access it at any time for medical assistance.

health facilities.question: What should students do in case of a medical emergency?
health facilities.answer: In case of a medical emergency, students can call the Health Centre helpline at 044 3993 1100 or visit the Health Centre near Academic Block 2. Ambulance services are also available for emergencies.

health facilities.question: Is the Health Centre equipped to handle emergencies?
health facilities.answer: Yes, the Health Centre is equipped with observation beds, a consultation room, doctors, staff nurses, and 2 ambulances to handle medical emergencies.

health facilities.question: Can students consult a doctor at the Health Centre?
health facilities.answer: Yes, students can consult a doctor at the Health Centre in the consultation room.

health facilities.question: Are there any charges for using the Health Centre facilities?
health facilities.answer: The document does not specify any charges for using the Health Centre facilities. Students should contact the Health Centre directly for more information.

health facilities.question: What is the role of the Apollo Shine Foundation at the Health Centre?
health facilities.answer: The Apollo Shine Foundation manages and operates the Health Centre, providing medical services to students.
